articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7b5 in G# (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Dominant 7b5 Chord in G# (Shape: E)

## Description
The Dominant 7b5 chord, also known as the half-diminished 7 chord, is a four-note chord comprising the root, major third, diminished fifth, and minor seventh. In the key of G#, when using the E shape, the notes of the Dominant 7b5 chord are G# (root), B# (major third), D# (diminished fifth), and F# (minor seventh).

## Notes and Intervals
- Root: G#
- Major Third: B#
- Diminished Fifth: D#
- Minor Seventh: F#

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7b5 chord is commonly found in jazz and fusion genres. Its dissonant yet colorful sound adds tension to chord progressions, providing a jazzy and dynamic flavor to the music. This chord is often used as a passing chord or in harmonic substitutions to create movement and interest in the music.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the Dominant 7b5 chord in G# (Shape: E):
1. Song: "So What" by Miles Davis
2. Song: "Blue Bossa" by Kenny Dorham
3. Song: "Impressions" by John Coltrane
